class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Ftechnology%20media%20and%20telecommunications%2Ftelecommunications%2Four%20insights%2Ffiber%20opportunity%20four%20deal%20types%20for%20investors%20to%20consider%2Ffiber-opportunity-four-deal-types-for-investors-to-consider-f.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="fiber-opportunity-four-deal-types-for-investors-to-consider-f" data-layer-report-name="fiber-opportunity-four-deal-types-for-investors-to-consider-f>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (8 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Fiber networks were once regarded</strong> as a high-risk asset class. Yet as fiber technology has proved its worth over the past decade, so these assets have grown to become some of the most popular among private equity and institutional investors seeking the stable, long-term cash flows that infrastructure can offer. In 2021, 94 deals were made for fiber assets, approximately 80 percent of which (75 deals) were for fiber-to-the-x (FTTX) networksâthe term used to describe a range of network architectures that primarily connect households to broadband services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f62356b-0a9c-423f-afaf-ee434089162c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f62356b-0a9c-423f-afaf-ee434089162c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">FTTX refers to the various ways of deploying fiber to consumers, in which X can be replaced with H for home, P for premise, N for node, B for basement or building, and C for curb.</span></span></span></a></span> Thirty-six of those deals disclosed the amount paid, which totaled $33 billion. That compares with 84 deals the previous year, with about $30 billion paid for 29 of them (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/fiber%20opportunity%20four%20deal%20types%20for%20investors%20to%20consider/svgz-fiber-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="In the technology, media, and telecom sector, infrastructure deal activity is strongest for fiber assets." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/fiber%20opportunity%20four%20deal%20types%20for%20investors%20to%20consider/svgz-fiber-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Deals have become increasingly expensive due to their popularity, however. Between 2018 and 2021, earnings multiples averaged 16.8, compared with 19.7 in 2021.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e27467f1-6d8c-48af-a30b-939df9a27381"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e27467f1-6d8c-48af-a30b-939df9a27381" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Fiber transaction multiples data, 2018â22, Dgtl Infra, accessed September 30, 2022; and Preqin, accessed October 4, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Multiples at these levels can make the business case hard to prove in certain markets, where subscriptions would have to exceed those witnessed to date. When it comes to greenfield rollouts, for example, McKinsey analysis suggests that in some markets, 80 percent of all households would be required to subscribe to the providerâs network to achieve an internal rate of return above 10 percent over 25 years.</p>
<p>Higher interest rates and hence increased cost of capital, along with the fact that many of the fiber assets that are most attractive to investors have already been sold, raise still additional considerations for would-be investors, making it reasonable to ask whether the fiber popularity tide could be about to turn. In the first nine months of 2022, deal activity was down slightly (46 deals compared with 49 in the first nine months of 2021), while the overall value of those deals dropped by as much as 21 percent (Exhibit 2). Yet average multiples crept higher still, reaching 22.5 in the period.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/fiber%20opportunity%20four%20deal%20types%20for%20investors%20to%20consider/svgz-fiber-ex2-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The number of fiber deals dropped slightly in the first nine months of 2022, but overall deal value fell by 20 percent." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/fiber%20opportunity%20four%20deal%20types%20for%20investors%20to%20consider/svgz-fiber-ex2-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>These numbers are highly influenced by the mix of deals. Earnings multiples have typically been in the range of 25 to 33 for wholesale fiber companies such as Open Fiber Italy, Orange Concessions France, and Uniti Australia, but lower for smaller, regional companies that have retail arms, such as TalkTalk in the United Kingdom and Vocus in New Zealand. Notwithstanding, our own research and experience suggest there remains scope for many more value-creating deals.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Join McKinsey at MWC 2023</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="https://mwc.mckinsey.com/" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c" target="_blank"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Learn more and register here</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>To begin with, there is strong underlying growth in the sector. Data traffic is expected to expand by around 20 percent annually in the next five years,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="94bbd01d-40ca-4f7b-9709-c94b016feebd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="94bbd01d-40ca-4f7b-9709-c94b016feebd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Ericsson mobility report</em>, Ericsson, June 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> and fiber is arguably the only fixed-broadband technology currently capable of delivering the speed and capacity expected by governments, businesses, and consumers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1c7b6c44-1d78-4b44-9b63-b60178ab8af8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1c7b6c44-1d78-4b44-9b63-b60178ab8af8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Fiber currently offers speeds of up to 10 gigabits per second (Gbps), which is faster than any older fixed technologies (for example, DSL and cable) and newer mobile and satellite ones. Docsis 3.1 and 5G fixed wireless access have speeds of 1 Gbps and LEO satellite has 5â25 megabits per second.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Fiber companies also offer steady EBITDA marginsâtypically above 40 to 50 percent for those providing broadband to consumers, and as high as 70 percent for those that offer wholesale services. But perhaps the biggest consideration is that millions of households still do not have a fiber connection. That represents a huge capital deployment opportunity.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Fiber technology is universal; fiber markets are local</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Fiber investment opportunities</strong> vary widely depending on the target market (exhibit). The competitive dynamics, regulation, and capital expenditure needs will vary in different local markets in any given country, depending largely on the extent of the fiber built. Markets typically fall into one of three broad categories:</p>
<p><strong><em>Greenfield markets:</em></strong> Capital spending requirements in these markets are still significant, accounting for $253 billion, or 60 percent of total fiber spending envisaged in coming years to connect households. Emerging markets in Asia, Africa, and South America, where less than 30 percent of households have access to fiber, are considered greenfield, as are a few Western ones, such as Germany, Greece, and Belgium. Here, extensive legacy networks and regulatory frameworks have hindered fiber build-out.</p>
<p><strong><em>Acceleration markets:</em></strong> These markets have significant fiber coverage. Between 30 and 60 percent of households have access to fiber provided by one or more large players. Investments to the tune of some $131 billion are required to connect the remainder. Several European markets fall into this category, including the United Kingdom and Austria, as does the United States.</p>
<p><strong><em>Mature markets:</em></strong> More than 60 percent of households have access to fiber in these markets, which means the opportunity for investment lies in connecting households in rural areas and converting those still using hybrid fiber-coaxial networksâan opportunity worth some $39 billion. Separating assets is also an opportunity in mature markets.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/fiber%20opportunity%20four%20deal%20types%20for%20investors%20to%20consider/svgz_fiber_exsidebar-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="At least $420 billion is still needed to make fiber accessible to all households in 87 countries." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/fiber%20opportunity%20four%20deal%20types%20for%20investors%20to%20consider/svgz_fiber_exsidebar-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Our analysis of 87 countries suggests that while some â¬900 billion has already been spent laying FTTX networks, at least another â¬400 billion is needed to connect all households in those same countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7da278b1-5bba-40c5-ac22-3810d439733c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7da278b1-5bba-40c5-ac22-3810d439733c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on McKinsey analysis of households already connected to fiber and those without fiber connections in 87 countries. Deployment costs are based on GDP per capita-adjusted costs to build per household, accounting for variable labor costs.</span></span></span></a></span> Household access to fiber services is, of course, higher in some countries than others and can be broadly divided into three groupsâgreenfield, acceleration, and mature markets (see sidebar, âFiber technology is universal; fiber markets are localâ). Yet opportunities also lie in FTTX deals that create more value from fiber already laid.</p>
<p>For private infrastructure investors that are considering the sector, some opportunities remain to buy fiber companies outright, but this is not the only way to acquire assets. Weâve examined four different types of deals also worth assessment. Each is attractive for different reasons, is suitable in different markets, depends upon different factors for success, and faces different challenges. We have seen these deal types create value in markets where other types of deals may be prohibitively expensive.</p>
<h2>Four value-creating deal strategies</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Four deal strategies merit consideration: partnerships with incumbents or new fiber players, the acquisition of challenged fiber players, the consolidation of smaller players, and the acquisition of an incumbent with a view to separating out the fiber assets.</p>
<h3>1. Partnerships or joint ventures with incumbents or others to deploy more fiber</h3>
<ul>
    <li><em>The attraction:</em> Deals with an incumbent come with a ready-made deployment plan and an established base of paying customers. There could also be a valuable match of capabilities: the incumbentâs operational experience and market knowledgeâof the regulatory environment and deployment topography, for exampleâand the private investorâs capital deployment discipline. Deals with other types of companies that do not yet have their own fiber infrastructureâa mobile or cable company, for example, or a utilityâcan also prove attractive because of the advantages these companies often enjoy in local markets, not least of which is an existing customer base.</li>
    <li><em>Relevant markets:</em> All. But these deals are most likely to appeal to operators in greenfield and acceleration markets that are cautious about spending more capital to upgrade existing networks, particularly at a time when 5G requires heavy investments.</li>
    <li><em>Key success factors and/or challenges:</em> Joint ventures with an operator come with the security of an anchor tenant and hence stable returns, though these might be relatively low, given competition among fund managers searching for investment opportunities and the returns required by the incumbent operator. In addition, exit opportunities could be limited, as some operators might struggle to buy out investors or be unwilling to lose control of part of their fiber infrastructure through a stock market listing. Previous fiber investments, and hence experience, could help investors secure deals. Note, however, that experience gained in one geography is not always easy to transfer for a variety of reasons, such as different regulations and the local marketâs readiness for high-end broadband services.</li>
</ul>
<p>Recent examples of these kinds of deals include TelefÃ³nicaâs partnerships with investment company CDPQ in Brazil to form FiBrasil. Launched in July 2021, FiBrasil rolled fiber out to 500,000 households in the course of six months and plans to reach another 5.5 million homes and businesses within four years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="07cbf1a9-e75e-4566-a0f8-6ca4e038231c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="07cbf1a9-e75e-4566-a0f8-6ca4e038231c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âFiBrasil, joint venture between Grupo TelefÃ³nica and CDPQ, starts operations in Brazil,â TelefÃ³nica, May 23, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In Colombia, also in 2021, TelefÃ³nica joined forces with KKR to form ON*NET Fibra, aiming to connect 4.3 million premises in 90 cities over three years. In October 2022, it announced it had already connected two million homes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="25706e72-3115-4640-b18d-10ceaf684a96"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="25706e72-3115-4640-b18d-10ceaf684a96" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âTelefÃ³nica Colombia and KKR announce leading company for FTTH deployment,â TelefÃ³nica, July 19, 2021. See also âON*NET Fibra exceeds 2 million homes deployed with fiber optics in Colombia in just 8 months,â Impacto TIC, October 3, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>2. Acquisition of challenged fiber players with a view to improving and expanding existing operations</h3>
<ul>
    <li><em>The attraction:</em> An opportunity to bring private equity investorsâ traditional strengths to bear, improving the performance of fiber companies that are struggling to meet the commercial and operational targets initially set, often because of increased competition and slower-than-expected consumer uptake.</li>
    <li><em>Relevant markets:</em> Acceleration markets where there is either a significant opportunity to deploy more fiber or to increase uptake of existing fiber. (In greenfield markets there are few fiber players to buy, while in some mature markets, previous consolidation means there arenât many challenged players remaining.)</li>
    <li><em>Key success factors and/or challenges:</em> Requires expertise in fixed network operations and a strong turnaround plan, starting with an understanding of the root causes of the companyâs performance issues and how they can be addressed. Strong knowledge of not just the national but also the local telecom market is a must.</li>
</ul>
<p>There have been few deals of this nature to date. However, just as they once featured in the cable and fixed telecom sectors, so they are likely to grow in number as the fiber market matures.</p>
<h3>3. Consolidate smaller fiber players</h3>
<ul>
    <li><em>The attraction:</em> Consolidation creates economies of scale, be it nationally or internationally.</li>
    <li><em>Relevant markets:</em> Mature and acceleration markets where the primary remaining opportunity lies in building scale. In mature fiber markets, where numerous small fiber companies remain, this strategy could drive the next wave of deals. In the United Kingdom, for example, there are more than ten such companies, while Brazil has more than 5,000, the vast majority of which have only 5,000 subscribers or less.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a4493287-8f73-4b54-8dba-04ff014359a8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a4493287-8f73-4b54-8dba-04ff014359a8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">UK company data: Global Comms Database Service, TeleGeography. Of the 5,795 fiber players in Brazil, 385 companies, or just 7 percent, have five thousand or more subscribers as of August 2022. The remaining 5,410 fiber players across Brazil have less than or equal to five thousand subscribers; Fixed Broadband Database, Brazil National Telecommunications Agency (Anatel), accessed August 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Key success factors and/or challenges:</em> Fiber company mergers have more limited synergies than mobile company mergers given the fixed, local infrastructure that tends not to overlap geographically. Investors therefore need to be sure of the value that might lie in operational improvements such as integration of the network architecture, or in the synergies in customer service and operating platforms.</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of this type of deal include the acquisition and merger of Germanyâs Inexio and Deutsche Glasfaser by private equity firms EQT and Omers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4627ea24-beb2-4b48-88a3-1641825da05b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4627ea24-beb2-4b48-88a3-1641825da05b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âEQT and OMERS acquire Deutsche Glasfaser, a leading provider of fiber-optic internet access in Germany,â EQT, February 10, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> EQT has also bought and merged multiple fiber companies in the Netherlands,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cc3d30cd-a5d3-48d3-bfef-76a86578600c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/how-we-help-clients">Technology, Media & Telecommunications Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/how-we-help-clients/telecommunications-operators" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Telecommunications Operators page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h3>4. Acquire an integrated operator with a view to separating the network from the retail business</h3>
<ul>
    <li><em>The attraction:</em> The combination of a stable, revenue-generating platform and a clear value-creating opportunity to grow a wholesale business as a neutral carrier.</li>
    <li><em>Relevant markets:</em> Mostly acceleration and mature markets. Many incumbents and other integrated telcos have already sold their towers to investors. Separating out the fiber network could create the next wave of deals.</li>
    <li><em>Key success factors and/or challenges:</em> This type of deal would be highly complex, would likely incur significant one-off costs, and would take time (between two and five years) to complete. Additionally, some question the tangible value of separating out fixed assets. There may be value to be gained by introducing wholesale services in some markets. But if these already exist, the acquisition and separation is an arbitrage strategy achieved at considerable expense.</li>
</ul>
<p>The separation of TelefÃ³nica O2 in the Czech Republic into O2 and CETIN is a key example. The combined market capitalization of the separated companies more than doubled in five years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5e22994b-085a-4790-a369-a2076ac886e7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Other separations are under way or being considered, such as those by TDC in Denmark,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span completes partial demerger of OpCo, NetCo,â TeleGeography, June 12, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> SÃ­minn in Iceland,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" to acquire MÃ­la, Icelandâs largest telecoms infrastructure company,â Ardian, October 25, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> and Telecom Italia.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a <h2>Keys to success: The basics</h2>
<p>The success of many of these deal types will depend on getting some basics right. Investors will need a thorough understanding of the local market context, particularly when laying new fiber. In one market, for example, the collapse of a major construction company exacerbated a labor shortage, making it hard to deploy capital quickly. In other markets, consumers and businesses have proven slow to switch to fiber, still not yet embracing the use-cases that fiber enables such as high-quality video or fast-paced gaming, seemingly satisfied with digital subscriber and hybrid fiber-coaxial lines.</p>
<p>No matter the deal type, investors will also need a value creation playbook that goes beyond efficiency in capital deployment if they are to meet their internal rate of return objectives. The ability to combine new assets with those already ownedâa customer base or legacy network, for exampleâor experience separating assets could prove important, as could the ability to lower operational and maintenance costs and drive fiber uptake with commercial excellence.</p>
<p>In addition, all investors should maximize the value of the infrastructure by looking beyond household connections. There are opportunities in fiber-to-the-office or fiber-to-the-business, metro fiber networks, backhaul for mobile, and edge computing, for example.</p>
<p>There are risks too, of course. Companiesâ rush to build fiber and regulatorsâ efforts to promote competition by encouraging multiple fiber networks could result in overcapacity and overlapping networks. And while fiber might be todayâs fixed-broadband technology winner, future competition from new technologies cannot be ruled out. In some mature markets in the United States and Europe, where cable penetration is high, Docsis 4.0 is potentially a cheaper way to upgrade the network, even though more upgrades might be required to keep pace with fiberâs expected future performance. <a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/is-there-a-best-owner-of-satellite-internet">LEO satellites</a> have also met with some success, as has 5G fixed wireless access (FWA) in areas with limited fiber. In India, Reliance Jio recently announced plans to reach 100 million households through 5G FWAâdeployment at a scale that could significantly change the technologyâs economics.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f95b60e0-5241-45f4-b737-d81c924a0417"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f95b60e0-5241-45f4-b737-d81c924a0417" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Surajeet Das Gupta, âReliance Jio eyes 100 mn homes through its 5G fixed wireless access,â <em>Business Standard</em>, August 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Still other technologies may yet materialize. But the magnitude of the opportunity in fiber markets is one that merits exploration around the globe, tailoring strategies to local market conditions to capture maximum value.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/gerardo-de-geest">Gerardo de Geest</a></strong> is a partner in McKinseyâs Amsterdam office, <strong>Lorraine Salazar</strong> is a senior knowledge expert in the Singapore office, <strong>Eivind TÃ¸rstad</strong> is a partner in the Oslo office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/martin-wrulich">Martin Wrulich</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Vienna office.</p>

opportunity Four deal types for investors to consider","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"d400795a-9d95-4677-8925-df09b59b34c2","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Fiber opportunity: Four deal types for investors to consider"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Investing in fiber cable: Four broadband opportunities"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"High investor demand has put a premium on fiber networks that deliver broadband connections to households, but there is still scope for more value-creating deals."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-12-14T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFiber networks were once regarded\u003c/strong\u003e as a high-risk asset class. Yet as fiber technology has proved its worth over the past decade, so these assets have grown to become some of the most popular among private equity and institutional investors seeking the stable, long-term cash flows that infrastructure can offer. In 2021, 94 deals were made for fiber assets, approximately 80 percent of which (75 deals) were for fiber-to-the-x (FTTX) networks\u0026mdash;the term used to describe a range of network architectures that primarily connect households to broadband services.[[footnote 1]] Thirty-six of those deals disclosed the amount paid, which totaled $33 billion. That compares with 84 deals the previous year, with about $30 billion paid for 29 of them (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eDeals have become increasingly expensive due to their popularity, however. Between 2018 and 2021, earnings multiples averaged 16.8, compared with 19.7 in 2021.[[footnote 2]] Multiples at these levels can make the business case hard to prove in certain markets, where subscriptions would have to exceed those witnessed to date. When it comes to greenfield rollouts, for example, McKinsey analysis suggests that in some markets, 80 percent of all households would be required to subscribe to the provider\u0026rsquo;s network to achieve an internal rate of return above 10 percent over 25 years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHigher interest rates and hence increased cost of capital, along with the fact that many of the fiber assets that are most attractive to investors have already been sold, raise still additional considerations for would-be investors, making it reasonable to ask whether the fiber popularity tide could be about to turn. In the first nine months of 2022, deal activity was down slightly (46 deals compared with 49 in the first nine months of 2021), while the overall value of those deals dropped by as much as 21 percent (Exhibit 2). Yet average multiples crept higher still, reaching 22.5 in the period.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThese numbers are highly influenced by the mix of deals. Earnings multiples have typically been in the range of 25 to 33 for wholesale fiber companies such as Open Fiber Italy, Orange Concessions France, and Uniti Australia, but lower for smaller, regional companies that have retail arms, such as TalkTalk in the United Kingdom and Vocus in New Zealand. Notwithstanding, our own research and experience suggest there remains scope for many more value-creating deals.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo begin with, there is strong underlying growth in the sector. Data traffic is expected to expand by around 20 percent annually in the next five years,[[footnote 3]] and fiber is arguably the only fixed-broadband technology currently capable of delivering the speed and capacity expected by governments, businesses, and consumers.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFiber companies also offer steady EBITDA margins\u0026mdash;typically above 40 to 50 percent for those providing broadband to consumers, and as high as 70 percent for those that offer wholesale services. But perhaps the biggest consideration is that millions of households still do not have a fiber connection. That represents a huge capital deployment opportunity.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eOur analysis of 87 countries suggests that while some \u0026euro;900 billion has already been spent laying FTTX networks, at least another \u0026euro;400 billion is needed to connect all households in those same countries.[[footnote 5]] Household access to fiber services is, of course, higher in some countries than others and can be broadly divided into three groups\u0026mdash;greenfield, acceleration, and mature markets (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Fiber technology is universal; fiber markets are local\u0026rdquo;). Yet opportunities also lie in FTTX deals that create more value from fiber already laid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor private infrastructure investors that are considering the sector, some opportunities remain to buy fiber companies outright, but this is not the only way to acquire assets. We\u0026rsquo;ve examined four different types of deals also worth assessment. Each is attractive for different reasons, is suitable in different markets, depends upon different factors for success, and faces different challenges. We have seen these deal types create value in markets where other types of deals may be prohibitively expensive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFour value-creating deal strategies\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eFour deal strategies merit consideration: partnerships with incumbents or new fiber players, the acquisition of challenged fiber players, the consolidation of smaller players, and the acquisition of an incumbent with a view to separating out the fiber assets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Partnerships or joint ventures with incumbents or others to deploy more fiber\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe attraction:\u003c/em\u003e Deals with an incumbent come with a ready-made deployment plan and an established base of paying customers. There could also be a valuable match of capabilities: the incumbent\u0026rsquo;s operational experience and market knowledge\u0026mdash;of the regulatory environment and deployment topography, for example\u0026mdash;and the private investor\u0026rsquo;s capital deployment discipline. Deals with other types of companies that do not yet have their own fiber infrastructure\u0026mdash;a mobile or cable company, for example, or a utility\u0026mdash;can also prove attractive because of the advantages these companies often enjoy in local markets, not least of which is an existing customer base.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRelevant markets:\u003c/em\u003e All. But these deals are most likely to appeal to operators in greenfield and acceleration markets that are cautious about spending more capital to upgrade existing networks, particularly at a time when 5G requires heavy investments.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eKey success factors and/or challenges:\u003c/em\u003e Joint ventures with an operator come with the security of an anchor tenant and hence stable returns, though these might be relatively low, given competition among fund managers searching for investment opportunities and the returns required by the incumbent operator. In addition, exit opportunities could be limited, as some operators might struggle to buy out investors or be unwilling to lose control of part of their fiber infrastructure through a stock market listing. Previous fiber investments, and hence experience, could help investors secure deals. Note, however, that experience gained in one geography is not always easy to transfer for a variety of reasons, such as different regulations and the local market\u0026rsquo;s readiness for high-end broadband services.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecent examples of these kinds of deals include Telef\u0026oacute;nica\u0026rsquo;s partnerships with investment company CDPQ in Brazil to form FiBrasil. Launched in July 2021, FiBrasil rolled fiber out to 500,000 households in the course of six months and plans to reach another 5.5 million homes and businesses within four years.[[footnote 6]] In Colombia, also in 2021, Telef\u0026oacute;nica joined forces with KKR to form ON*NET Fibra, aiming to connect 4.3 million premises in 90 cities over three years. In October 2022, it announced it had already connected two million homes.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Acquisition of challenged fiber players with a view to improving and expanding existing operations\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe attraction:\u003c/em\u003e An opportunity to bring private equity investors\u0026rsquo; traditional strengths to bear, improving the performance of fiber companies that are struggling to meet the commercial and operational targets initially set, often because of increased competition and slower-than-expected consumer uptake.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRelevant markets:\u003c/em\u003e Acceleration markets where there is either a significant opportunity to deploy more fiber or to increase uptake of existing fiber. (In greenfield markets there are few fiber players to buy, while in some mature markets, previous consolidation means there aren\u0026rsquo;t many challenged players remaining.)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eKey success factors and/or challenges:\u003c/em\u003e Requires expertise in fixed network operations and a strong turnaround plan, starting with an understanding of the root causes of the company\u0026rsquo;s performance issues and how they can be addressed. Strong knowledge of not just the national but also the local telecom market is a must.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere have been few deals of this nature to date. However, just as they once featured in the cable and fixed telecom sectors, so they are likely to grow in number as the fiber market matures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Consolidate smaller fiber players\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe attraction:\u003c/em\u003e Consolidation creates economies of scale, be it nationally or internationally.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRelevant markets:\u003c/em\u003e Mature and acceleration markets where the primary remaining opportunity lies in building scale. In mature fiber markets, where numerous small fiber companies remain, this strategy could drive the next wave of deals. In the United Kingdom, for example, there are more than ten such companies, while Brazil has more than 5,000, the vast majority of which have only 5,000 subscribers or less.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eKey success factors and/or challenges:\u003c/em\u003e Fiber company mergers have more limited synergies than mobile company mergers given the fixed, local infrastructure that tends not to overlap geographically. Investors therefore need to be sure of the value that might lie in operational improvements such as integration of the network architecture, or in the synergies in customer service and operating platforms.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExamples of this type of deal include the acquisition and merger of Germany\u0026rsquo;s Inexio and Deutsche Glasfaser by private equity firms EQT and Omers.[[footnote 9]] EQT has also bought and merged multiple fiber companies in the Netherlands,[[footnote 10]] and FiberCop, owned by TIM, KKR, and Fastweb, has done the same in Italy.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up dis1]]\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Acquire an integrated operator with a view to separating the network from the retail business\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe attraction:\u003c/em\u003e The combination of a stable, revenue-generating platform and a clear value-creating opportunity to grow a wholesale business as a neutral carrier.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRelevant markets:\u003c/em\u003e Mostly acceleration and mature markets. Many incumbents and other integrated telcos have already sold their towers to investors. Separating out the fiber network could create the next wave of deals.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eKey success factors and/or challenges:\u003c/em\u003e This type of deal would be highly complex, would likely incur significant one-off costs, and would take time (between two and five years) to complete. Additionally, some question the tangible value of separating out fixed assets. There may be value to be gained by introducing wholesale services in some markets. But if these already exist, the acquisition and separation is an arbitrage strategy achieved at considerable expense.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe separation of Telef\u0026oacute;nica O2 in the Czech Republic into O2 and CETIN is a key example. The combined market capitalization of the separated companies more than doubled in five years.[[footnote 12]] Other separations are under way or being considered, such as those by TDC in Denmark,[[footnote 13]] S\u0026iacute;minn in Iceland,[[footnote 14]] and Telecom Italia.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eKeys to success: The basics\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe success of many of these deal types will depend on getting some basics right. Investors will need a thorough understanding of the local market context, particularly when laying new fiber. In one market, for example, the collapse of a major construction company exacerbated a labor shortage, making it hard to deploy capital quickly. In other markets, consumers and businesses have proven slow to switch to fiber, still not yet embracing the use-cases that fiber enables such as high-quality video or fast-paced gaming, seemingly satisfied with digital subscriber and hybrid fiber-coaxial lines.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo matter the deal type, investors will also need a value creation playbook that goes beyond efficiency in capital deployment if they are to meet their internal rate of return objectives. The ability to combine new assets with those already owned\u0026mdash;a customer base or legacy network, for example\u0026mdash;or experience separating assets could prove important, as could the ability to lower operational and maintenance costs and drive fiber uptake with commercial excellence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, all investors should maximize the value of the infrastructure by looking beyond household connections. There are opportunities in fiber-to-the-office or fiber-to-the-business, metro fiber networks, backhaul for mobile, and edge computing, for example.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are risks too, of course. Companies\u0026rsquo; rush to build fiber and regulators\u0026rsquo; efforts to promote competition by encouraging multiple fiber networks could result in overcapacity and overlapping networks. And while fiber might be today\u0026rsquo;s fixed-broadband technology winner, future competition from new technologies cannot be ruled out. In some mature markets in the United States and Europe, where cable penetration is high, Docsis 4.0 is potentially a cheaper way to upgrade the network, even though more upgrades might be required to keep pace with fiber\u0026rsquo;s expected future performance. \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/is-there-a-best-owner-of-satellite-internet\"\u003eLEO satellites\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;have also met with some success, as has 5G fixed wireless access (FWA) in areas with limited fiber. In India, Reliance Jio recently announced plans to reach 100 million households through 5G FWA\u0026mdash;deployment at a scale that could significantly change the technology\u0026rsquo;s economics.[[footnote 16]] Still other technologies may yet materialize. But the magnitude of the opportunity in fiber markets is one that merits exploration around the globe, tailoring strategies to local market conditions to capture maximum value.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-12-14T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFTTX refers to the various ways of deploying fiber to consumers, in which X can be replaced with H for home, P for premise, N for node, B for basement or building, and C for curb.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFiber transaction multiples data, 2018\u0026ndash;22, Dgtl Infra, accessed September 30, 2022; and Preqin, accessed October 4, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEricsson mobility report\u003c/em\u003e, Ericsson, June 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFiber currently offers speeds of up to 10 gigabits per second (Gbps), which is faster than any older fixed technologies (for example, DSL and cable) and newer mobile and satellite ones. The competitive dynamics, regulation, and capital expenditure needs will vary in different local markets in any given country, depending largely on the extent of the fiber built. Markets typically fall into one of three broad categories:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eGreenfield markets:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Capital spending requirements in these markets are still significant, accounting for $253 billion, or 60 percent of total fiber spending envisaged in coming years to connect households. Emerging markets in Asia, Africa, and South America, where less than 30 percent of households have access to fiber, are considered greenfield, as are a few Western ones, such as Germany, Greece, and Belgium. Here, extensive legacy networks and regulatory frameworks have hindered fiber build-out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eAcceleration markets:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e These markets have significant fiber coverage. Between 30 and 60 percent of households have access to fiber provided by one or more large players. Investments to the tune of some $131 billion are required to connect the remainder. Several European markets fall into this category, including the United Kingdom and Austria, as does the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eMature markets:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e More than 60 percent of households have access to fiber in these markets, which means the opportunity for investment lies in connecting households in rural areas and converting those still using hybrid fiber-coaxial networks\u0026mdash;an opportunity worth some $39 billion. Separating assets is also an opportunity in mature markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit sidebar]]"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Fiber technology is
